Ian Badcoe wrote:

>Hi,
>         This is a thought I have had for some time, but not got around to 
>posting.
>
>         w.r.t your test, I would use both types of neurone in the network 
>and pick a type for each one when it is first added.  Either that or some 
>how allow additive and multiplicative inputs.
>  
>

Hi Ian,  you hinted at a number of interesting areas in your email, and 
hopefully I will get chance to research and experiment soon regarding 
different types and configurations of neurons and networks. I agree that 
we don't want to slavishly follow nature, but at the same time the basic 
functioning of natural neural nets is a lot more complex and subtle than 
the basic models we have all been using to date. I can definitely see 
how the presence of one particular neuro-transmitter may enhance the 
effect of another - and that this essentially describes a neuron that is 
multiplying it's inputs. And if you think about how many 
neuro-transmitter chemicals there are and the plethora of different ways 
they might be interacting, well who knows what important interactions we 
might missing out on.

Colin.
